article.title: SDSS IV MaNGA: Discovery of an $H_Î±$ blob associated with a dry galaxy pair -- ejected gas or a `dark' galaxy candidate?

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of galaxies are Satsuki and Mei?
choices: Spiral galaxies
Elliptical galaxies
Irregular galaxies
Lenticular galaxies

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the approximate diameter of the MaNGA hexagonal bundle field of view (FoV)?
choices: 5 arcsec
10 arcsec
20 arcsec
32.5 arcsec

multiple_choice_question.text: Based on the Ha flux map, what is unusual about the Ha emission in this system?
choices: There is a giant Ha blob located far from any visible galaxy.
The Ha emission is concentrated solely in the center of Satsuki.
There is no detectable Ha emission from Mei.
The Ha flux is uniformly distributed throughout the FoV.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be inferred from the smooth appearance of the reconstructed ugr image (left panel)?
choices: The MaNGA data has poor resolution and cannot resolve individual stars.
There is no significant ongoing star formation in the region of Totoro.
The presence of dust obscures the underlying stellar population.
The reconstructed image is based on an inaccurate model of the galaxies.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the [OIII]+Ha+[NII] composite image (right panel) primarily highlight?
choices: The distribution of old stellar populations
The extent of the dust lanes in the system
The regions of ionized gas emission
The presence of a strong AGN jet

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the spectra of Satsuki and Mei indicate about their stellar populations?
choices: They are composed primarily of young, hot stars.
They are dominated by old stellar populations.
They show evidence of recent starburst activity.
Their spectra are featureless and provide little information.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the primary characteristic of Totoro\'s spectrum?
choices: Strong absorption lines indicating a large population of old stars
A flat spectrum with no prominent features
Strong emission lines, indicative of ionized gas
A strong continuum dominated by non-thermal emission

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the most striking difference between Totoro and the two galaxies (Satsuki and Mei)?
choices: Totoro has a much higher star formation rate (SFR).
Totoro has a significantly lower ionized gas mass (MHII).
Totoro has a much smaller stellar mass (M*).
Totoro has a much larger amount of molecular gas (MH2).

multiple_choice_question.text: What information does the table provide about the possibility of ongoing star formation in Totoro?
choices: Totoro has a high SFR, indicating active star formation.
Totoro has no detectable SFR, suggesting a lack of star formation.
The SFR of Totoro is uncertain due to the upper limit on Ha flux.
Totoro has a SFR comparable to that of Satsuki and Mei.
